DIGITAL Network Appliance Reference Design: software download

The following software is intended for use in an environment consisting of one or more DNARD Network Computers and a supporting server, which is typically an x86 PC running FreeBSD.

Instructions for using these files to set up such an environment are provided in:

  • The DNARD User's Guide (Adobe PDF format)

See also the bug listpage for a list of known bugs.

NOTE: These sourcefiles (NetBSD and XFree86, dated 7 April 1998) and client file system image (dated 13 April 1998) represent a complete clean rebuild of the system, including the GNU tools. In particular, this update brings the DNARD software up to release 1.3 of NetBSD. We recommend that all current DNARD partners download these files and do a full upgrade of their existing servers. (Naturally, the source snapshots are needed only for those components that you are planning to rebuild.)

DNARD client software

  • NetBSD Operating System -- based on NetBSD 1.3
    • full sources (1998.04.07 -- 55MB)
    • kernel-only sources (1998.04.07 -- 11MB)
  • XFree86 X-server -- based on XFree86 3.3
    • full sources (1998.04.07 -- 37MB)
    • source diffs from XFree86 3.3 release (1998.04.07 -- 61KB)
  • Client file system image
    • root filesystem
      • root with /etc (1998.04.13 -- 5.7MB) for installing new servers
      • root without /etc (1998.04.13 -- 5.6MB) for upgrading existing servers
        Note: Remove "-etc" from filename before upgrading
        • /etc only as example of proper setup for NetBSD 1.3
    • /usr filesystem (1998.04.13 -- 23MB)
    • /usr/X11 filesystem X Window System (1998.04.13 -- 20MB)

Server software

  • DHCP server
    • executable for FreeBSD (1997.07.24 -- 150KB)
    • executable for DIGITAL UNIX (1997.08.27 -- 150KB)
  • Server Configuration Utility
    • complete kit (1997.11.14 -- 650KB)

Note 1: All of the above links are ftp-based. The easiest way to download is to simply
click on them in the browser. (If necessary, force file-save -- e.g. shift-click in Netscape
Navigator.) If Internet transmission problems make the larger files difficult to download,
you may wish to note the URLs and use a standalone ftp client that provides a "reget"
command.
